['Teapot - Traditional container used to hold tea leaves and water during the brewing process.', 'French press - A device consisting of a beaker or cylinder equipped with a plunger, which is ideal for steeping coffee grounds before pressing them down through a filter.', 'Coffee mug - Often used to hold ground coffee leaves when using a drip-brew method.', 'Herbal infuser - A device designed specifically for holding herbs and flowers while brewing in water, commonly associated with tea but applicable to herbal infusions as well.', 'Kettle - Typically used for boiling water, though it can be paired with a teapot or similar container to hold leaves during the brewing process.', 'Moka pot - An Italian stove-top coffee maker that uses ground espresso coffee and steam pressure to brew coffee directly into a cup below the filter.', 'Cone steeper - A handheld device with a cone shape, used for infusing loose tea leaves in hot water without needing a secondary container.', 'Chamomile bag - A simple bag made from cloth or paper, often used to hold chamomile flowers while brewing herbal teas.', 'Mason jar - While not specifically designed for leaf-brewing, mason jars can be repurposed as a makeshift vessel with proper filtration systems during the brewing process.', 'Tea ball or infuser - A small container typically made from metal, silicone, or porcelain used to hold tea leaves and herbs while steeping in hot water without loose leaves floating around.', 'Mini French press - Smaller version of the classic French press suitable for holding smaller quantities of leaves during brewing.', 'Glass pitcher - Can be employed as a vessel when brewing leaf-based teas or coffee, though it is not designed specifically for that purpose.', 'Tea tray - A serving platter used to present and store tea sets before the actual brewing process occurs, but can also act as a secondary container during brewing in some cases.', "Yixing teapot - A traditional Chinese ceramic pot specifically crafted for holding and brewing tea leaves; its shape and material are designed to enhance the tea's flavor over time with repeated use.", 'Tea strainer or sieve - A tool used after steeping, typically held within a larger container like a teapot or pitcher, to separate the leaves from the brewed liquid.', 'Hibashi (teabowl) - A Japanese ceramic cup specifically designed for holding tea leaves and hot water during the infusion process in the traditional matcha preparation method.', 'Teacup - Although typically used to hold a small amount of brewed leaf-based beverage, larger teacups can accommodate loose leaves within them if using an appropriate infuser.', 'Honeycomb filter (used with tea bags) - A mesh paper wrapper designed for holding tea leaves and allowing the water to permeate through while retaining the leaves during brewing in a mug or pot.', 'Teapot stand - While not directly involved in holding leaves, this accessory supports and secures a teapot during use; some stands might be designed with additional space for loose leaves if used with an infuser.', 'Enameled kettle (teakettle) - An enameled metal container typically used to boil water but can also accommodate a tea strainer or infuser filled with leaves when preparing tea using the pour-over method.']
